title: Starter home scheme cemented by £26m fund
text:
Ministers back £26m fund to buy sites for starter homes Helen Warrell, Public Policy Correspondent ©Getty 
Ministers are investing £26m in a new fund to acquire brownfield sites which will be set aside for the development of properties for first-time buyers. 
The financing, announced by communities secretary Greg Clark on Monday, aims to boost the government’s initiative to build 200,000 starter homes by the end of this parliament. More Farnes mark 90 years in National Trust 
Once the government has purchased the land, architects, developers, councils, housing associations and small builders will compete to acquire individual sites, and proceeds from these sales will be diverted back to the Exchequer. The homes built on the new sites will be offered to young first-time buyers at a 20 per cent discount, under the government’s Help to Buy scheme. 
Explaining the deal, Mr Clark said the fund would help ensure a “wide range of new properties” were available to those ready to start out on the housing ladder. 
“We are also helping bring back into use more brownfield land for development, keeping the country building and delivering the homes our communities need,” he added. 
Ministers signalled that housebuilding would be one of their priorities in office by setting out ambitious targets in the Queen’s Speech , including the 200,000 new homes pledge. A new Housing Bill will offer 1.3m housing association tenants big discounts to buy their homes, with receipts channelled towards building more affordable housing for other aspiring homeowners. 
In addition, the government is bringing forward proposals to ensure that every “reasonably-sized” housing site includes a proportion of starter homes, and will look into exempting developers from certain levies if they are building first-time properties. 
Chancellor George Osborne’s summer Budget included the introduction of automatic planning permission on designated brownfield sites to speed developments on empty plots. He also took aim at “Nimby” councils by introducing a new law which would allow ministers to impose a housing plan on a local authority if it had failed to produce one, as well as penalties on councils that failed to process planning applications quickly. 
Responding to Monday’s announcement, Andy Rose, chief executive of the Homes and Communities Agency, said his organisation was ready to support the government in delivering more high-quality starter homes. 
“We look forward to working with our key delivery partners including councils, developers, housing associations, small builders and architects in taking this forward, through the identification and purchase of land suitable for exemplar Starter Home sites,” he said. Related Topics
